Communist Party of the United States of America Records

Simon W. Gerson held several leadership roles at the district and national levels of the CPUSA. He was the political action director for the New York District, and later for the national CPUSA, advocating for proportional representation and ballot access for minor political parties. He served as Confidential Examiner to Manhattan Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, managed Communist election campaigns, and organized activities in support of the Communist Party leaders indicted under the Smith Act. Gerson was also indicted under the Smith Act. In the 1950s he was executive editor of the Daily Worker, and of its successor, the Daily World. This subseries illustrates Gerson's extensive involvement in the political work of the CPUSA. Materials from his time as Gus Hall's campaign manager during Hall's bids for the United States presidency, as well as a large cache of clippings on national elections dating back to the 1950s, can be found here. A portion of this subseries also provides evidence of Gerson's interest and involvement in the persecution of communists through legislation such as the Smith Act.
